top_comment.text:
You can tell those cops are new and inexperienced on the field. Was 
expecting threats of arrest for "disorderly conduct". Also the cop wearing 
the sunglasses was fiddling with his little blue notebook, showing signs of 
anxiety (probably because of the camera) which is a natural reaction for 
most people who are being filmed. The way he was unsure about the legality 
of the prank was also a sign that he was not confident about the law, 
therefore giving in and letting the pranksters continue. An experienced cop 
would tell the pranksters that they are disrupting a lot of people and at 
first politely ask them to stop but then will resort to threatening arrest 
even after knowing that the prank is harmless. But since they were called 
out to check it out, they wouldn't want their "authoritative" pride to get 
tarnished by these pranksters by walking away empty handed so they'll 
arrest first, ask questions later.﻿

comments.text:
+monsterjamkid02
I think I haven't seen more than 5 native english speakers in my whole 
life, the thing is that spanish speakers use english because it's "cool". 
Wich is kinda dumb because some people don't know what "On sale" Means, for 
example.
 Another thing is that we use words like "Sorry" in some cases, for example 
if a friend says he only likes expensive restaurants, we would say "oooh 
sorry, el millonario...."
By "Sorry" we mean "watch out!" and then we would say something like "Hes a 
millionaire!"
comments.author: Enematron

comments.text:
+Enematron That's interesting! Do you happen to live in a tourist area that 
would have a lot of English speakers? Or does the whole country just 
encourage English?
comments.author: monsterjamkid02

comments.text:
We are surrounded by english all the time, and we learn the basics at 
school, so from one way or another, you end up learning quite a lot of the 
language to be a foreigner.
Music, culture, movies, shop signs, etc.
In some shops it says "On sale" Instead of "Oferta" (Wich means on sale) 
and that's just a small example.

I watch so many youtube videos from americans that I can't talk without 
using an American accent. That's a disadvantage because if I travel there I 
won't have that sexy latino accent :(
comments.author: Enematron

comments.text:
+Enematron I've noticed that it's a difficult language to learn, haha. I 
can't even imagine learning English though, between its, it's, there, 
they're, your, you're, etc.
comments.author: monsterjamkid02

comments.text:
Yeah, the thing is that spanish is a hard ass language to learn, with so 
many stupid words like la les los
it makes it so hard to remember. You don't always need those words before a 
verb tho. If you want to say "It was a pleasure", you can simply say "Fue 
un placer", Wich literally would mean "Was a pleasure"
You can put "Esto" wich means  "IT" but not in this phrase.. it would be 
weird.

ÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑÑ
comments.author: Enematron

comments.text:
+Enematron Not sure if it is slightly different in Europe. We learn 
'western' Spanish only, and we've been told that you always need the le, 
la, les, las, nos, whatever before a verb. I might just be forgetting 
something, because I haven't practiced Spanish since late last year.

Thanks for the help though, I appreciate it. I'm hoping to become a cop and 
it is much easier to become a US cop if you are fluent in Spanish.
comments.author: monsterjamkid02

comments.text:
"Fue" means "It was" so you don't need to use IT

in fact, to replace pronouns like He, She, It, we use different words wich 
indicate what person we are talking about
For example, If you say Me gusta, Le gusta, Les gustan, you just change the 
words to indicate who you are taking about.
It's way simplier in english cause you use any pronoun followed by "Like" 
and you pretty much don't have to change anything else.

I'm having dinner now, we can have a conversation later
comments.author: Enematron

comments.text:
+Enematron We were taught that 'le' means it. My intentions were 'It was a 
pleasure.' How would I correctly include the 'it'? Or do native speakers 
not use it?

Thanks.
comments.author: monsterjamkid02

comments.text:
"Le fue"
sounds like french, I got you there. it makes no sense at all
remove "Le"
"Fue un placer" = "Was a pleasure" (I know you already know, but the "Le"

comments.author: brandmannetje

comments.text:
+brandmannetje Not true. In Iceland the cops say "NO" many times. I've 
personally had that happen to me 3 times when I called them for serious 
stuff. Also the cops here don't follow the laws themselves. People think 
the police here is so genuine and fine but it's not true. Once I called the 
cops when 3 men where trying to break into my home and the police told me 
to "shut up" on the phone. Another time I was at a party and the police 
showed up with 4 officers and broke into the apartment with no warrent. 
That's how it is here. Once my friend was arrested with 1 gram of pot and 
he got no charges because the cops stole his pot for themselves. I can tell 
you 100 more stories.
comments.author: Kartafla

comments.text:
When a person calls dispatch they must follow protocol and send an police 
unit. Its pretty much in every country. Police can't say no we will not go. 
Eventually when they arrive and it was a pointless call they can fine u for 
that. And be honest if multiple people call the cops for weird voices that 
goes arround a park that does raises qeustions. Its not like the cops came 
with sirens blazing.
